channel.title: A Homemade computer from scratch
channel.description:
This thing I'm working on works off a 556 timer (STOP LAUGHING!) All that it can do is add a few numbers and display a few letters. I got all my parts from radioshack, exept the Mac Keyboard. The keyboard is probably 5 years old, but I made it work with the computer. I've been trying to make an lcd screen work with it.
It takes up very little power, because it runs off usb. Ill update this later.

item.title: A Homemade computer from scratch
item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

So your making a CPU or a computer using existing cpu??

Read full topic

item.title: A Homemade computer from scratch
item.dc:creator: @benny679 benny679
item.description:
@benny679 wrote:

Honestly I don’t know much about making 4 bit computers like the one I’m making. Mine doesn’t have a “real” cpu, I use the 555 timer to redirect wires, thats all. Everything that it does isn’t controled by the cpu, it’s just a mess of wires… but I’m working on making a real cpu that will control it, it will be much easier for the user that way. And for me to build it.

Yes, I would like the nvram.

So heres my question. If I had the user change say… which led’s will light up, the nvram will save that? I’m a beginner… sorry.

EDIT: So I have an led screen make up a number. the number 1 is defualt. When you hit the 7 key, it makes a 7. When you let go, it will go back to 1. Can ram make it so it stays a 7? And then nvram, so when you shut it off, and turn it back on, it will be there. Then if you click the 7 it will remove the 7 and go to 1. Is that possible?

Read full topic

item.title: A Homemade computer from scratch
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“benny679, post:4, topic:360846”]CAT28C16AL: 2 kilobyte EEPROM (used to store programs)
CAT22C10LI20: Hybrid NVRAM; 4 bit I/O, 6 address bits (used for RAM)
CD74HCT193EE4: 4-bit binary up/down counter with data reset

Are those good choices?[/quote]
Instead of you buying a 644 NVRAM, I could send you a couple of 211As they are 2564 and are really simple to hookup I’m using them for the stack on my CPU, send me a PM if you are interested.

What are you using the 4bit up/down for?

Read full topic

item.title: A Homemade computer from scratch
item.dc:creator: @benny679 benny679
item.description:
@benny679 wrote:

CAT28C16AL: 2 kilobyte EEPROM (used to store programs)
CAT22C10LI20: Hybrid NVRAM; 4 bit I/O, 6 address bits (used for RAM)
CD74HCT193EE4: 4-bit binary up/down counter with data reset

Are those good choices?

Read full topic

item.title: A Homemade computer from scratch
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

What are you making it from TTL? I’m also building a homebrew processor, 8bit RISC 64k SRAM 256 I/O 1k stack, you can find some vlogs on it here and documentation on it here. I’d like some more infomation about your homemade computer! What are you building it with, on what some more specs would be good.

Read full topic
